Articles: Military Families are Outing Obama Military Families are Outing Obama By Karin McQuillan American military and State Department families that have lost their sons in the war against Islamic jihadis are outing President Obama for playing politics with the lives (and deaths) of their sons. Speaking out in some of the most painful interviews ever shown on television, they directly blame the president for the loss of their sons' lives. Their accusations speak directly to Obama's competence in defending our national security. Iran is on the brink of possessing nuclear weapons. Egypt's elected President Mubarak, the keystone to stability in the Middle East for the last 30 years, was pressured by President Obama to step down in favor of the terror group the Muslim Brotherhood. The Benghazi embassy was denied Marine protection, even on 9/11, with the subsequent tragedy and White House cover-up. We haven't lost an ambassador since Jimmy Carter's incompetence. Obama's Middle East policy has been a disaster, with one exception -- the killing of Osama bin Laden by Navy SEAL Team 6. The president ran the special ops raid on Osama bin Laden's compound with one eye on national security and the other on political opportunism. Intelligence was compromised because there was political advantage to Obama to do so. Within a day, the White House divulged details of the attack, including that it was carried out by SEAL Team Six. Three months later, 22 men from SEAL Team 6 were dead, victims of Obama's policies and politics. This story has been buried, until this 9/11. Aaron Vaughn Aaron's mother, Karen Vaughn, has a simple message: "How dare they -- they put a target on my son's back and even on my back! A little over 90 days later, my son was dead." Sean Hannity ran a searing interview with Karen and Billy Vaughn, parents of a fallen Navy SEAL Team Six serviceman, Aaron Vaughn. It deserves repeated viewing. Aaron signed up to serve after 9/11 and was killed in Afghanistan in 2011 after the Osama raid, along with 21 other SEALS -- the single greatest disaster in the Afghanistan war and Navy Special Forces history. Robert Gates, the defense secretary at the time, was appalled at President Obama and Vice President Biden boasting about the raid in detail: "We all agreed that we would not release any operational details from the effort to take out bin Laden. That all fell apart the next day." Karen Vaughn: Aaron called me, his tone was extremely serious and he said, mom, you need to wipe your social media clean. Get rid of everything. Any reference of me or my buddies because there is chatter and all of our lives are possibly in danger, including yours. Karen Vaughn says that her son told her the SEALs were angry that their secrecy was compromised by the White House. Aaron felt that it put not only his life, but also the lives of 300 American military families in danger. She adds, "I can tell you that the community was stunned by the [White House] announcement. It was unprecedented and extremely dangerous." As the mother speaks, Aaron's father, Billy Vaughn's face is so full of grief and anger, I can hardly look at him. He looks like he might explode if not for intense self-control. Billy's face was more searing than his wife's words. I don't think I will ever forget it. Then it is his turn to speak. These elite warriors can do anything they want to the Taliban, to al Qaeda if this administration -- if President Obama would just recognize the enemy, give them rules of engagement that favor them, instead of leveling the playing field for the enemy, and give them the equipment that is required to carry out their missions. And I mention those three things because those are other issues that we have found in searching and looking at what happened to Aaron and those warriors on that night, all three of those things were -- were reasons why this chopper was shot down. Why this largest loss in a single day in the 10-year war on terror was caused and also the largest loss in the history of naval special warfare. ...Our president is directly responsible for the rules of engagement. Let me just say this. On the night that Extortion 17 was shot down, this is all from the military -- we learned that the Afghan National Army, the Afghan National Police, the Afghan Security Ministry, are all involved in every single special ops mission, in the pre-planning, the post-op. They know the flight routes of the choppers. That chopper flew in there that night in a place that had already been cleared seven times, according to our military, by our warriors and turned back over to the Afghans. A 3 1/2-hour firefight under way and our chopper flew in with an AC-130 gunship in the air, two H-64s and they were not allowed to give any pre-assault fire. They landed the chopper like it was landing at Wal-Mart even though a firefight was underway. When the chopper was shot down, neither were the AC-130 or the two AH-64s allowed to take out the savages who fired the RPGs because they were standing on a tower. And under the rules of engagement, they didn't know if there might be friendlies in the building. These rules of engagement are criminal for our warriors. In an interview the Vaughns gave this 9/11, Billy said: "We expect better out, out of the, the high-ups in our government. We, as American citizens, look to our government. We elect them; we look to them to take care of the best interests of the American citizen, and especially the warrior. And I believe what the administration did then -- I believe it was criminal." A little-told side to President Obama's running of the war in Afghanistan is the fact that the rules of engagement there are deadly to American soldiers. Under President Obama, average yearly deaths in Afghanistan have doubled. The Obama administration is denying our troops air support and threatening them with prosecution for firing in self-defense. Returning military are protesting, but their voices are not reported in the mainstream media (read here, here, here). Sean Smith There was another heart-wrenching interview the evening before the Ryan-Biden debate that did make it onto prime-time news -- on CNN, no less. Anderson Cooper interviewed Pat Smith, the mother of Sean Smith, father of three, an Air Force veteran and computer specialist who was murdered in the terrorist attack in Benghazi this 9/11. He was my only child. ... I look at TV and I see bloody hand prints on walls, thinking, my god, is that my son's? I don't know if he was shot. I don't know -- I don't know. They haven't told me anything. They are still studying it. And the things that they are telling me are just outright lies. That Susan Rice, what -- she talked to me personally and she said, she said, this is the way it was. It was -- it was because of this film that came out. COOPER: So she told you personally that she thought it was a result of that video of the protest? SMITH: Oh, absolutely. Absolutely. In fact all of them did. All of them did. Leon Panetta actually took my face in his hands like this and he said, trust me. ...at first I was so proud because they were treating me so nice when I went to that reception. They all came up to me and talked to me and everything. I cried on Obama's shoulder. And he -- then he'd kind of looked off into the distance. So that was worthless to me. I want to know, for god's sakes. It's my son. I had him for the first -- I told Obama personally, I said, look, I had him for his first 17 years and then he went into the service, then you got him. And -- I won't say it the way I said it. But I said you screwed up, you didn't do a good job, I lost my son. The Obama administration denied the embassy the military security they repeatedly requested. The embassy was forced to rely on hired locals instead of Marines. According to State Department Regional Security Officer Eric Nordstrom, at the congressional hearings held October 11 on the Benghazi cover-up, "in deference to sensitivity to Libyan practice the guards at Benghazi were unarmed." Mr. Nordstrom said that he was forced to a lesser security profile due to reduced staffing. As a result, instead of man-to-man defense, they had to move to zone defense. In other words, they had to rely on help from other areas in the case of an attack while sheltered in a facility that did not meet minimum requirements. Obama lied to the American public in order to promote his major political talking point -- that al-Qaeda was defeated because of bin Laden's death. The administration's false claims of success were put above the safety of our embassy personnel. That is what Pat Smith was referring to when she said to Obama to his face, "You screwed up, you didn't do a good job, I lost my son." Joseph Logan A third story is also receiving coverage -- in the U.K.'s Daily Mail, that is, and on Fox News and Sean Hannity's radio web page. The father of fallen Marine Joseph Logan is speaking out about the condolence form letter he received from President Obama, delivered by a UPS truck driver almost five months after his son's remains were brought home from Afghanistan. The father, Tom Logan, experienced Obama's late, impersonal form letter as profoundly disrespectful: "It opened up a wound, a hole in our heart, that you can't fix." Tom Logan sent the form letter back to the Oval Office with a personal, hand-written message written across the bottom: You, Sir, are an embarrassment to the Oval Office. ... Your ridiculous rules of engagement have caused the massive amount of casualties on your watch in Afghanistan. While we watch your media pander to your administration and clearly sweep things under the rug for you. I understand Marines die. You have tied their hands and feet! I am thankful that I did not serve under a Commander in Chief such as you. I am sickened that my son had to. The families of the 21 Navy SEALs killed three months after the Osama raid also received form condolence letters, each with a huge Barack Obama signature that looked as if it was signed by an automatic pen. Obama did have the time to send a personal letter to rapper Heavy D's family when he passed away, to be read before a crowd of 1,500 at Heavy D's star-studded funeral. It is not as if writing condolence letters would be a big burden on Obama's busy schedule. The Department of Defense reports 1,650 combat deaths in total in Afghanistan since the beginning of the war in 2001. That's a rough average of 150 deaths a year. Obama has played a hundred rounds of golf with White House staffers but can't write a single condolence letter every other day. The contrast with President Bush is remarkable. Bush (who played golf 24 times and then stopped playing in deference to the troops) sent personal letters to the families of "every one of the more than 4,000 troops who have died in the two wars, an enormous personal effort that ... escaped public notice." President Bush also met privately with "more than 500 families of troops killed in action and with more than 950 wounded veterans ... outside the presence of the news media." The first lady (Laura Bush) said those private visits, many of which she also attended, took a heavy emotional toll, not just on the president, but on her as well...."People say, 'Why would you do that?'" the president said in an Oval Office interview with The Washington Times on Friday. "And the answer is: This is my duty. The president is commander in chief, but the president is often comforter in chief, as well. It is my duty to be - to try to comfort as best as I humanly can a loved one who is in anguish. These military and State Department families who have lost their sons since 2008 have lost respect for Obama as commander in chief. They are angry that their sons' lives are cheap to Obama, and their deaths not treated as worthy of his personal attention. As Pat Smith says so eloquently: "You screwed up, you didn't do a good job, I lost my son." Or Billy Smith: "These rules of engagement are criminal for our warriors." Tom Logan: "I understand Marines die. You have tied their hands and feet! I am thankful that I did not serve under a Commander in Chief such as you." All Americans can say the same: in playing politics with national security, Obama is not looking out for our lives. Click to expand...

Not so sure about that "pre-release" OK being a necessity. (as Mustachio noted in his edit) Andrew Sullivan posted a couple of notes he received from readers who claim to be State Dept workers - maybe yes, maybe no but the comment about how long it takes for a full approval to go thru the bureaucracy does strike me as true. I'm a former US Foreign Service officer and can tell you that the statement by the US Embassy in Cairo - which, frankly, seems perfectly OK to me to begin with; what's really so offensive about it that the Obama administration has to "distance" itself from it? - almost certainly wasn't cleared with DC, because otherwise it wouldn't have been issued for another day or two! It would have spent that time bouncing back and forth from the Egypt desk up to the Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern Affairs and over then to Public Affairs and God knows who else getting massaged, tweaked, edited and finally OK'd. The reason embassies have Public Affairs officers is so they can handle this sort of statement on their own, though doubtless the DCM, acting as charge d'affaires in the absence of the ambassador, signed off on it. I've written about this in several other threads, chasing down your failures to accurately describe WHY there is such slow job growth, even after the technical recession is over. But, you don't care that a liquidity based economy is different than a manufacturing based economy and you don't care that such a infrastructural differential will mean slower than normal economic recover on the jobs scene. All you want to do is score what you think are political points, while never being honest enough to realize just how weak your argument is in the light of what real economists like Northwestern University's Robert Gordon, Harvard's Jeffrey Frankel, and Stanford's Robert Hall have declared about WHY are economy will not be able to put on job growth as seen in the past - given the structural differentials between the economy of 1980/1982 and 2007/2008. You also have failed to demonstrate that you know anything about the well known concept of Economic Momentum. Even a small child could understand that, if you put a bowling ball at the top of a tilted plank and allowed it to roll to the bottom, that the ball would have more Momentum near the bottom of the tilted plank, than it would while at rest near the top, or at any point along its path to the bottom. Intuitive, you could demonstrate that to a small child and they would understand it - intuitively, even if they could not describe the Newtonian Mathematics that drive it. Similarly, you could describe to that same small child, the concept of a near $14 trillion economy, retaining "some" of its negative momentum even AFTER a technical recession has been declared as being no longer in existence and especially when that economy was so dependent on liquidity from China, Germany and Japan. You know, trying to discuss this matter with you like an adult, has proven to be utterly impossible - because you continually inject your irrational "numbers" into a formula that simply rejects your inputs as being insufficient to calculate a result. thread_title: Moral condemnation is not enough

author: Real-Patriot-1776
snippet: In every democracy, there is a civic responsibility to educate yourself on the candidates. This responsibility has been failed in mass. Pluralism, must stop with fascism. It as a political ideology has absolutely zero redeeming qualities. Those who advocate for it out of ignorance, malice, or both are too dangerous to continue allowing their politi…
text: In every democracy, there is a civic responsibility to educate yourself on the candidates. This responsibility has been failed in mass. Pluralism, must stop with fascism. It as a political ideology has absolutely zero redeeming qualities. Those who advocate for it out of ignorance, malice, or both are too dangerous to continue allowing their political participation. Those who have voted for him a second, and third time must have their right to vote revoked. J6ers and ICE officers need to be treated as the violent traitors they are, and tried for treason. Those republicans in power and any complicit democrats, must be removed from power and barred from ever holding office again. I reject the notion of reconciliation after the term, and I believe the correct moral response is punitive ostracization. Sadly, one thing they have gotten correct is that this is an existential battle between good and evil. Democracy and authoritarianism. I reject compromise, I reject reconciliation, I reject the sanitization of their actions. They deserve neither Liberty, nor Safety. Every accusation of theirs is a confession, I believe wholeheartedly. They have cheered, watching legal residents get sent to foreign death camps in chains. These are the actions of vermin. This may make me hateful, or a hypocrite. But I was molded in their image. I get to watch, the democracy I believe in get violated. The values I believe in turned inside out. My countrymen, suffering and dying due to a tyrant's negligence. The natural response, is rage. They asked for hate, they voted to remove the disease from this country's halls of power. On this, we agree. Towards fascists, there is only one appropriate response. Extinction. One does not compromise with the devil, one does not sanitize his actions, one does not pretend he is a moral actor. He is resisted, rooted out, and rejected. People have died. Children have died. That blood is on their hands, whether they choose to acknowledge it or not. Tolerance, should never have been extended to fascist traitors. What can we common people do? We may not be able to remove them from power currently, or put them on trial for their crimes. But, we can ostracize them. We can cease sanitizing the behavior of rats. Our silence is complicity. We must give them a reason to want to take their flags down, while not letting them. Forgiveness died the moment they sent people to CECOT. They have proven that they are unworthy of moral consideration. They don't give that consideration to others. Reciprocity is my word of the day. I refuse to pretend they are anything but a cancer. Who are the decadent, moral degenerates? Probably those who make excuses for a child predator. Who is the enemy within? Probably those who appease our historic enemies, abandon our allies, and storm our capital building. Even their God would reject them, as he values children highly, and has commanded them to heal the sick, feed the poor, and welcome the foreigner. They are wretches by any ethical metric but their own. They are undeserving of the patience we have shown them. It's time we acknowledge this, loudly. They are an existential threat to our democracy, and common decency everywhere. If that isn't clear by now, then it never will be. 1. The ability to participate in our democracy, should not extend to fascists 2. Examples must be made of both ICE officers, and J6ers 3. Trump and his cronies must never be allowed anywhere near public office again 4. Anti-competitive practices by tech billionaires must be addressed, as it allows for disproportionate influence on the levers of power 5. Limitations on campaign funding by corporate entities must be established 6. Those who have voted for this a second, and third time deserve to be ostracized 7. The Supreme Court needs to be emptied of authoritarians, and term limits established I agree with the quote in my signature, and I reject the notion of reconciliation after Trump's term. Those who voted for him again, are either egregiously ignorant, outright malicious, or both. Educating yourself on the candidates is a civic responsibility, which they have failed to meet. Unfortunately, this ignorance has caused actual permanent harm. Which they ignore, as it doesn't effect them. I advocate for the identification of all Trump voters, and their subsequent removal from political participation entirely. I advocate for the expeditious removal of all republicans from power, any complicit democrats, followed by barring them from ever holding public office in this nation again. I believe ICE officers & J6ers should be put on trial for treason, as well as the senior officials within the administration. Our democratic institutions need a reboot, if our democracy is to survive. We must stop catering to, and sanitizing fascists. Moral condemnation is only the first step, it must be put into action.

page_title: When is law-breaking/civil disobedience justified for the sake of a greater political “good”? | Debate Politics
thread_title: When is law-breaking/civil disobedience justified for the sake of a greater political “good”?
forum_path: Home > Forums > DP Blogs
author: blur
snippet: A ramble of sorts: Many on both the left and right do appear to believe that breaking the law or civil disobedience is justified in certain circumstances for the sake of greater positive outcome. But they can’t seem to agree on when that is. For the right, there was January 6th, and the targeting of a federal building with important political figur…
text: A ramble of sorts: Many on both the left and right do appear to believe that breaking the law or civil disobedience is justified in certain circumstances for the sake of greater positive outcome. But they can’t seem to agree on when that is. For the right, there was January 6th, and the targeting of a federal building with important political figures inside, including the Vice President. They stole and destroyed property, violently attacked police officers, and they refused orders from law enforcement. But while, despite Trump’s pardons, there are some who would say that they regret their actions, there are others who believe it was justified for the sake of “saving democracy.” And though I think that these people had no logical, rational, or factual basis for their belief that democracy was in danger, many of them did appear to genuinely believe that was the case, and that the election was “stolen” and that politicians inside the Capitol were not only aware of that, but behind it. Alternately, we have ICE protesters, who genuinely believe that ICE is breaking the law by forcing their way into private properties without warrants, taking people based on skin color/accent and not just on actual legal status, and will justify the murder of a citizen for openly expressing opposition to their behaviors. As a result, these protestors, will follow ICE vehicles, document their behavior, and will warn others when they are around. Some would argue that these protesters are “obstructing justice.” Now, regardless of whether either side (or both or neither) are justified in their beliefs, they do both appear to be sincere in those beliefs even though both have faced accusations of being “anarchists” or “terrorists” when they believe that they are simply defending democracy and the Constitution. I suppose it could just come down to “ a little disobedience for me but not for thee.” But is it entirely rational to expect people who sincerely believe that civilians are facing an existential threat to not react in a way that might result in the disobeying or law/authority? Would it benefit public discourse more to focus less on the reaction (protests/civil disobedience/law-breaking) and more on whether the reaction is justified?

text: Re: Teaching liberals why we have religion: James972 said: of course if true you would not have been so afraid to explain what has replaced it. Do you learn anything from your fear? Click to expand... Nothing has replaced it. It's certainly still around. It has just been one among a number of other philosophies here in the west: pragmatism, postmodernism, humanism, pluralism, relativism, etc... and has become less attractive as we have realized that all cultures ascribe their latest opinions and cultural norms and beliefs to the order of nature and their gods and deities. And even as the culture changes over time, so does what they have their gods saying and wanting. Did you know that Muslims think it is "natural law" for women to cover their hair and face with a hijab for modesty? They can't understand why the women in the rest of the world so flagrantly violate such clear things in the order of nature. And, believe it or not, Christians even used to think human chattel slavery was part of the natural order of things as set up by God. Here is Alexander Stephens, the vice president of the confederacy, to explain: "Our new government is founded upon exactly the opposite idea; its foundations are laid, its corner-stone rests upon the great truth, that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery—subordination to the superior race—is his natural and normal condition. This, our new government, is the first, in the history of the world, based upon this great physical, philosophical, and moral truth." Click to expand... You think this was something he made up? And contrary to Christian teachings? Well here is the president of the Confederacy, to argue otherwise: ""Slavery was established by the decree of Almighty God. It is sanctioned in the Bible, in both testaments, from Genesis to Revelation." -Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederate States of America. Click to expand... So there ya go: using natural law philosophy and Christianity to argue for slavery. You can use "natural law" to argue anything. I am not sure natural law exists out in nature, or whether the regularities we see out in nature and the cosmos are just some kind of accidental thing. There may or may not be. The scientists themselves are not quite sure themselves. But even if there is, that doesn't help me try to decide how to organize my bookshelf or my room. I am not sure how it would be different for the larger society in which I live either. Just because the planets go around the sun in a certain regular way or the four seasons exist still does not help me decide whether the sweaters should get folded and put away in the drawer, or hung up in the closet. And it certainly doesn't help me decide whether women should be allowed to vote, or slavery made illegal, or gays allowed to get married. All of these different things just have consequences, some foreseeable with some reasonable foresight and judgment, and some not so foreseeable. But just yelling "natural law" to push forward my latest opinions on how things should be ordered is not, I have found, a helpful argument.

snippet: phattonez said: Why are the only options allowed so regulated? For instance, I want a plan that covers me if I get hit by a bus or develop cancer, pure catastrophic coverage. Why can't I have that? Click to expand... To clarify and reiterate Rabid Alpaca's comments: Insurance -- ANY kind of insurance -- is about distributing risk among the ratepaye…
text: phattonez said: Why are the only options allowed so regulated? For instance, I want a plan that covers me if I get hit by a bus or develop cancer, pure catastrophic coverage. Why can't I have that? Click to expand... To clarify and reiterate Rabid Alpaca's comments: Insurance -- ANY kind of insurance -- is about distributing risk among the ratepayers. The insurers collect insurance payments from people who don't currently need the services, and distribute payments to those who do need them. What this does is reduces the costs of premiums overall. There are numerous issues with health insurance "a la carte." • The essential health benefits pretty much are... essential. There isn't much fat to cut. • It will make plans more complex and confusing. At the moment, the ACA plans specify certain minimum requirements, so you should have a basic idea what you're getting. Even with those minimums and comparison tools in the exchanges, it's can be difficult to sort through plans. If the minimum coverages are removed, then it just gets more confusing, and ratepayers will assume they have coverage that they don't. • With the exception of men and maternity, you really never know in advance what you're going to need -- which is a major reason why we have insurance in the first place. E.g. you may not have a substance abuse problem today, but if your doctor prescribes an opiate-based painkiller, every day you take it increases the chance you'll become dependent on it. • On an aggregate level, it drives up the cost of care. As noted already, insurance distributes the cost over all ratepayers. The larger the pool of ratepayers, the lower the individual costs. So you personally might save a few bucks on your insurance, but doing so will drive the costs for pregnant women through the roof. Oh, and those maternity costs? They're a small percentage of your premiums: { "lightbox_close": "Close", "lightbox_next": "Next", "lightbox_previous": "Previous", "lightbox_error": "The requested content cannot be loaded. Please try again later.", "lightbox_start_slideshow": "Start slideshow", "lightbox_stop_slideshow": "Stop slideshow", "lightbox_full_screen": "Full screen", "lightbox_thumbnails": "Thumbnails", "lightbox_download": "Download", "lightbox_share": "Share", "lightbox_zoom": "Zoom", "lightbox_new_window": "New window", "lightbox_toggle_sidebar": "Toggle sidebar" } • Along those lines, allowing individuals to select items a la carte creates a freeloader problem. E.g. at the start of the year, you're in good health, so you opt out of most of the services, and go for a high deductible plan (or don't pay at all). Then, you develop an illness that requires an expensive medication for 6 months. You add better pharmaceutical coverage... and drop it when you go off the medication. The end result is that premiums as a whole become more expensive, because those who do pay have to make up for the gaps left by the freeloaders. This is why single-payer plans are generally more efficient. They spread the risk over much larger risk pools and more ratepayers, and do not tolerate freeloaders (since they are paying with taxes). This is also why Romney included mandates in his Heritage-sponsored plan. He referred to it as the "Personal Responsibility Principle." • The incentives don't just affect ratepayers, they also affect insurers. With no required minimums, they will craft cheap plans with minimal coverage, and make broad plans far more expensive. This will cause further distortions, as ratepayers go for the cheaper and skimpier plans. E.g. if you want a plan that covers cancer, you're going to get socked -- because the insurers won't be able to distribute the risk across all ratepayers. • Along those lines, it turns out that killing EHBs could actually increase costs for the government, at least under the disastrous AHCA. In that scenario, subsidies are based on age, ranging from $2000 to $4000 per person, per year. With EHB requirements in place, insurers can't hit that number -- but without them, they can offer skimpy plans that hit the target prices and... encourage people to get more plans that offer less coverage, and line the insurer's pockets at taxpayer expense. This may be why many Republicans refused to eliminate the EHB requirements. ( AHCA tweak could eliminate Essential Health Benefits - Business Insider ) Another way to put this is: In many circumstances, what is beneficial for the individual is detrimental for the nation as a whole. This should not be shocking to... well, anyone, really. Taxes are bad for the individual, but necessary for a nation to function. It's safe for you to not be a police officer or firefighter, but if everyone refuses to perform those duties, no one will be safe. Sometimes, you just gotta take one for the team.

text: Florida is reportedly sending police officers to the homes of people who signed a petition supporting an abortion rights ballot initiative. Someone asked the other day about what DeSantis has been doing in Florida lately, well here you go. Florida is reportedly sending police officers to the homes of people who signed a petition supporting an abortion rights ballot initiative. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis’s administration has begun investigating thousands of verified signatures that helped to put a state constitutional amendment protecting the right to abortion on the ballot in November. The amendment would overturn Florida’s current six-week abortion ban. Click to expand... Supervisors in Hillsborough, Orange, Palm Beach, Osceola, Alachua, and Broward counties have been requested to gather around 36,000 signatures for state review, according to the Tampa Bay Times. One supervisor with 16 years of experience told the Times that the state’s request was entirely unprecedented. Not only had the state requested signatures that had already been verified, but they did so for a validated petition, not a rejected petition, which are typically the basis of fraud investigations. Multiple residents in Lee County have reported being visited by law enforcement following up on their petition signatures. Click to expand... Lots of articles from other sources, but this one isn't paywalled.

text: Captain Mars said: Florida is reportedly sending police officers to the homes of people who signed a petition supporting an abortion rights ballot initiative. Someone asked the other day about what DeSantis has been doing in Florida lately, well here you go. Lots of articles from other sources, but this one isn't paywalled. Click to expand... This is not at all surprising. The Florida Legislature has a record of ignoring referendums passed by voters. They are now trying to give an excuse for ignoring the abortion referendum. Not only did they change the rules to make the minority the winners, they reserve the right to do nothing when a referendum passes. We now basically have a dictatorship where DeSantis makes the laws and the legislature passes them with a rubber stamp. Florida Citizens Decide Issues, Then Lawmakers Ignore Them (1) ​ Ballot initiatives need approval from 60% of voters New law limits contributions to ballot initiatives Florida voters may have thought they had the last word when they approved ballot initiatives legalizing medical marijuana, restoring voting rights to former felons, and raising the minimum wage. That’s not how lawmakers see it. “One of the main reasons that people use the initiative process of Florida is to bypass the Legislature,” said University of Central Florida state politics expert Aubrey Jewett. “On an issue that the Legislature doesn’t like, they have a long record of trying to undermine whatever was passed.” Plus lawmakers keep moving the goalposts, requiring larger percentages of the vote to win, adding restrictions on raising money, and making it harder to get initiatives on the ballot in the first place. A proposal being offered for the 2022 ballot grew out of that tension between legislators and voters. Advocates successfully campaigned in 2018 to automatically restore voting rights to former felons, but they were thwarted by a 2019 legislative requirement withholding those voting rights until ex-felons paid all court-ordered fees, fines, and restitution. https://about.bgov.com/news/florida-citizens-decide-issues-florida-lawmakers-ignore-them/

snippet: October 6, 2024 Washington and Massachusetts are stockpiling abortion pills. California is cutting climate deals directly with automakers. Colorado is rushing to protect the right to same-sex marriage. And attorneys general across the country are marshaling legal resources and privately plotting courtroom strategies. From the West Coast to the East…
text: October 6, 2024 Washington and Massachusetts are stockpiling abortion pills. California is cutting climate deals directly with automakers. Colorado is rushing to protect the right to same-sex marriage. And attorneys general across the country are marshaling legal resources and privately plotting courtroom strategies. From the West Coast to the East, blue states are preparing for the possibility that former president Donald Trump wins reelection in November by attempting to shield their policy priorities from the reach of a future Trump administration. This preemptive strategy — “Trump-proofing” — encompasses a wide range of issues and programs that Democratic leaders fear could be targeted in another Trump presidency, based on his previous actions and his current campaign promises. Even as they pursue such safeguards, Democrats are projecting confidence in their nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, but they say it would be irresponsible to go into Election Day without a backup plan for their worst-case scenario. Read more: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/10/06/democratic-states-trump-election-day-2024/

snippet: X Factor said: I agree that I've encountered resistance when I've said atheism requires it's own set of beliefs. That's usually when I'm told it's a lack of belief or faith. Why are atheists so adverse to the suggestion that they believe in something (in this case, that there is no god)? Click to expand... Atheists are adverse to people defining th…
text: X Factor said: I agree that I've encountered resistance when I've said atheism requires it's own set of beliefs. That's usually when I'm told it's a lack of belief or faith. Why are atheists so adverse to the suggestion that they believe in something (in this case, that there is no god)? Click to expand... Atheists are adverse to people defining them as believing in something by nothing else but faith. Consider that an atheist cannot believe in something without empiracle, unfalsifiable evidence. Atheism by itself does not have its own set of beliefs, but an atheist who also is a police officer, or an atheist who is also a doctor, or an atheist who is also a scientist, may have their own personal beliefs but it is not due to atheism, but due to their own observations and studies.

page_title: What's the Difference Between Atheists and Agnostics? | Debate Politics
thread_title: What's the Difference Between Atheists and Agnostics?
forum_path: Home > Forums > Debate Politics Forum > Archives > Religion & Philosophy
snippet: ADG said: Atheists are adverse to people defining them as believing in something by nothing else but faith. Consider that an atheist cannot believe in something without empiracle, unfalsifiable evidence. Atheism by itself does not have its own set of beliefs, but an atheist who also is a police officer, or an atheist who is also a doctor, or an ath…
text: ADG said: Atheists are adverse to people defining them as believing in something by nothing else but faith. Consider that an atheist cannot believe in something without empiracle, unfalsifiable evidence. Atheism by itself does not have its own set of beliefs, but an atheist who also is a police officer, or an atheist who is also a doctor, or an atheist who is also a scientist, may have their own personal beliefs but it is not due to atheism, but due to their own observations and studies. Click to expand... Well, you say on the one hand that atheism doesn't rest on a "set of beliefs." However, I disagree that this is accurate. Certainly you can't say atheism rests of a set of religious beliefs, but it does certainly rest on at least an epistemic claim, a set of beliefs as to what makes something true . As you observe, atheism is rooted in an absence of empirical evidence for divinity. However, empirical evidence is not the only sort of evidence. The materialist-atheist's epistemological claim that empirical evidence is the only grounds for truth, as opposed to, say, subjective or faith-based evidence on which a theist might base a truth-claim.

text: Re: Religion in decline. Quote Originally Posted by apdst View Post The Supreme Court can't interpret The Constitution. They don't have that power. Synopsis of each ratified amendment No. Subject 1st Prohibits the making of any law respecting an establishment of religion, impeding the free exercise of religion, abridging the freedom of speech, infringing on the freedom of the press, interfering with the right to peaceably assemble or prohibiting the petitioning for a governmental redress of grievances. 3rd Places restrictions on the quartering of soldiers in private homes without the owner's consent, prohibiting it during peacetime. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 4th Prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures and sets out requirements for search warrants based on probable cause as determined by a neutral judge or magistrate. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 5th Sets out rules for indictment by grand jury and eminent domain, protects the right to due process, and prohibits self-incrimination and double jeopardy. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 6th Protects the right to a fair and speedy public trial by jury, including the rights to be notified of the accusations, to confront the accuser, to obtain witnesses and to retain counsel. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 7th Provides for the right to trial by jury in certain civil cases, according to common law. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 8th Prohibits excessive fines and excessive bail, as well as cruel and unusual punishment. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 9th Protects rights not enumerated in the Constitution. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 10th Reinforces the principle of federalism by stating that the federal government possesses only those powers delegated to it by the states or the people through the Constitution. September 25, 1789 December 15, 1791 2 years 2 months 20 days 11th Makes states immune from suits from out-of-state citizens and foreigners not living within the state borders; lays the foundation for sovereign immunity. March 4, 1794 February 7, 1795 11 months 3 days 12th Revises presidential election procedures. 13th Abolishes slavery, and involuntary servitude, except as punishment for a crime. 14th Defines citizenship, contains the Privileges or Immunities Clause, the Due Process Clause, the Equal Protection Clause, and deals with post-Civil War issues. 15th Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on race, color, or previous condition of servitude. 16th Permits Congress to levy an income tax without apportioning it among the states or basing it on the United States Census. 17th Establishes the direct election of United States Senators by popular vote. 18th Prohibited the manufacturing or sale of alcohol within the United States. 19th Prohibits the denial of the right to vote based on sex. June 4, 1919 20th Changes the date on which the terms of the President and Vice President (January 20) and Senators and Representatives (January 3) end and begin. 21st Repeals the 18th Amendment and gives the States the power to prohibit or regulate the transportation or importation of alcohol for delivery or use. 22nd Limits the number of times that a person can be elected president: a person cannot be elected president more than twice, and a person who has served more than two years of a term to which someone else was elected cannot be elected more than once. 23rd Grants the District of Columbia electors (the number of electors being equal to the least populous state) in the Electoral College. 24th Prohibits the revocation of voting rights due to the non-payment of a poll tax or any other tax. 25th Addresses succession to the Presidency and establishes procedures both for filling a vacancy in the office of the Vice President, as well as responding to Presidential disabilities. 26th Prohibits the denial of the right of US citizens, eighteen years of age or older, to vote on account of age. 27th Delays laws affecting Congressional salary from taking effect until after the next election of representatives. So! Where exactly is the Amendment removing Prayer and Bible reading from Public Schools? Where is the Amendment taking away the right of a fetus?? Where is the Amendment allowing for "Gay" marriage? There are none, because the Supreme Court for about the last 50 has taken it upon itself the privilege to redefine the Constitution. Blacks needed amendments to be set free and to be allowed to vote. Women needed an amendment to be allowed to vote in federal elections. The Supreme Court has power because it has taken it! And the Congress, Senate, and President have allowed it because it gets THEM off the hook!

text: cpwill said: The question here from a purpose of justification is does the current regime lead to more suffering than the violence engaged in against it . So the relevant metric for this judgment is not "do attacks against PP advance the cause", but rather "are more people killed in abortion clinics from abortionists operating under the law, than are killed by people engaging in violence against them? Click to expand... Abortion terrorism does literally nothing to prevent any of that suffering (most of these clinics are up and running again within the week, with beefed up security and renewed resolve on the part of those running them), while also creating unnecessary disturbance and chaos. I would say that, in the context of Just-War theory, this is where we are. Planned Parenthood et. al. are not going to stop killing children unless they are forced to, and are uninterested in being persuaded to stop. Click to expand... Legal recourse is still available, and has even been successful in gradually cutting back on so called abortion "rights" in states with large Conservative majorities. Legitimate Authority becomes problematic when the Authority that is present is Unjust and viciously, brutally, murderously contrary to Gods' Law. Click to expand... Pre-meditated assaults upon clinics with deadly weapons go a bit beyond such intercession, especially considering the such clinics are protected by law. Again, this basically falls under sedition, which is held (by the Church anyway) to be a sin. While sedition can be imminently justified under certain circumstances, "lone wolf" terrorism really is not it... Even if the cause is undeniably just. You'd need a movement, with clear cut demands, rules of engagement, and the like, which actually had a snowball's chance in Hell of accomplishing its goals. I would say we have definitely established that. Click to expand... Yes. THIS is where I would say that attacks against PP clinics become problematic and wrong. They don't limit abortions, they simply give abortionists sympathy points. Click to expand... Yes. And I would say that this, additionally, would justify violence against the doers of violence who mass-murder children. More than 57 million unborn children have been killed in the United States by abortion since Roe v Wade. Click to expand... I'm not denying it. However, the methods under discussion in the OP simply are not the way of accomplishing such a thing. To the extent possible while achieving comparable military objectives. Agreed. Targeting those who murder children, however, is not targeting non-combatant civilians, anymore than firing back at someone who was shooting up a restaurant would be. You are targeting the violent with violence. Click to expand... It's accomplishing basically nothing, while killing and injuring a lot of civilians in the process. Either way, it fails the test. cpwill said: There are always alternatives available. For example, instead of fighting the Islamic State, we could all convert to Islam and submit ourselves to the rule of the Caliphate. That is an alternative . "Last Resort" does not mean "no other possible actions". It means non-violent alternatives to achieving your objectives have proven unsuccessful and are likely to continue to prove unsuccessful. Click to expand... Negative. That would be contrary to God's law, and therefore is not a reasonable demand. Correct, just as it is when I practice self-defense or the defense of any other. This is correct, and the major restraint against violence against abortionists. Click to expand... Again, open, violent defiance of civil law goes a bit beyond "self-defense." Either way, what we're talking about here doesn't work anyway, so it's kind of a moot point. :shrug: On the contrary, the ending of a mass-murder regime is indeed a restoration of peace. Click to expand... No, in practical terms, restoring peace is restoring peace. If you stop one evil, but basically destroy everything else of value in your society in the process, the "victory" is rather Pyrrhic at best. If you are taking part in or enabling abortions to occur, you are part of that process. You are no more a "non-combatant" target than you as an intel guy in uniform is in a regular shooting war, simply because you aren't a trigger puller. Click to expand... Does that justify killing police officers and elected officials? That's a rather slippery slope which "just war theory" was meant to avoid in the first place. It is a bad idea politically, and a bad idea because the use of violence in this context makes eventual victory less likely rather than more likely. Beyond that, it does not run afoul of the justifications for deadly force. Click to expand... Essentially, yes.

This latest man actually wound up killing and injuring almost as many police officers as he did any "legitimate" targets. While I will not deny that the cause in going after abortion clinics is just, and that the end game of doing away with them is good, terrorism really is not the "moral" way to go about accomplishing that. This is more apparent if one looks at more contemporary translations of the "Just War" theorem, which spell out a bit more clearly some things which Aquinas' more archaic language only implied. Principles of Just War ​ By principles 1, 2, 4, 5, and 7, (basically every other one) abortion terrorism fails to really measure up to the moral standard. 1. There are other alternatives available. 2. The authority behind waging war against the practice is in no way, shape, or form "legitimate." Usually, it is an individual decision. 4. There really is not any reasonable chance of success. 5. There is no coherent "end game" beyond simply trying to get rid of abortion, so the re-establishment of peace is hardly being accounted for. And, finally... 7. The terrorists responsible for the attacks often wind up indiscriminately killing and injuring large numbers of people who are not actually "guilty." By any common sense moral standard, let alone the Christian variety, it's simply a bad idea. :shrug: Click to expand... Great posts overall, throughout the thread; I especially enjoy reading Aquinas' teaching texts. I do have an question re the 'Just War' premises as it applies to judicial supremacy overrunning Constitutional supremacy re the current U.S. government, and how that would effect what is legitimate versus illegitimate re Christians obeying the 'Law', when the 'law' as determined by Federal district courts and the SCOTUS with no relation to the prevailing principles and traditions, which in essence just a form of arbitrary chaos and anarchy based on current whims and fashions. Christianity is amazing at self-correction over time, as its history shows, but should it really accommodate itself to abortions of convenience and the like, to name just one example? I'm an atheist, myself, and I see no reason to 'tolerate' mass slaughter and the dehumanization such practices encourage; it's the politics of self-indulgence carried to an extreme.

text: cpwill said: I would point out that your argument has a few holes. For example, use of: Yielding my own rights to avoid scandal is not the same as allowing, through inaction, the brutal murder of others. When it is the superior tribunal that is the unjust lawgiver who allows the murder of children, the condition on which this is predicated ceases to exist. And this is fulfilled in the just cause of both saving children and that those who are attacked are those who murder or seek to murder, or help to murder children. Concur. And, again, this can be (which does not mean that it is or will be fulfilled in the just cause of both saving children and that those who are attacked are those who murder or seek to murder, or help to murder children. Tell me, Gath. How many dead children v how many dead abortionists? It would take the killing of every abortionist - what, a dozen times over? - to cross this boundary. This is not only untrue, but it is tautologically untrue - terrorism is done expressly to achieve a political goal. Violence for it's own sake can certainly be horrific, but it isn't terrorism. Click to expand... These aren't really "holes," per se, because they're covered by the following. Summa Theologica Question 42. Sedition Consequently there is no sedition (sin) in disturbing a (unjust or tyrannical) government of this kind, unless indeed the tyrant's rule be disturbed so inordinately, that his subjects suffer greater harm from the consequent disturbance than from the tyrant's government. Click to expand... As this most recent event pretty conclusively proves, anti-abortion terrorism tends to cause a Hell of a lot more public disturbance than it does actually bring about any legitimate good. This latest man actually wound up killing and injuring almost as many police officers as he did any "legitimate" targets. While I will not deny that the cause in going after abortion clinics is just, and that the end game of doing away with them is good, terrorism really is not the "moral" way to go about accomplishing that. This is more apparent if one looks at more contemporary translations of the "Just War" theorem, which spell out a bit more clearly some things which Aquinas' more archaic language only implied. Principles of Just War 1. A just war can only be waged as a last resort. All non-violent options must be exhausted before the use of force can be justified. 2. A war is just only if it is waged by a legitimate authority. Even just causes cannot be served by actions taken by individuals or groups who do not constitute an authority sanctioned by whatever the society and outsiders to the society deem legitimate. 3. A just war can only be fought to redress a wrong suffered. For example, self-defense against an armed attack is always considered to be a just cause (although the justice of the cause is not sufficient--see point #4). Further, a just war can only be fought with "right" intentions: the only permissible objective of a just war is to redress the injury. 4. A war can only be just if it is fought with a reasonable chance of success. Deaths and injury incurred in a hopeless cause are not morally justifiable. 5. The ultimate goal of a just war is to re-establish peace. More specifically, the peace established after the war must be preferable to the peace that would have prevailed if the war had not been fought. 6. The violence used in the war must be proportional to the injury suffered. States are prohibited from using force not necessary to attain the limited objective of addressing the injury suffered. 7. The weapons used in war must discriminate between combatants and non-combatants. Civilians are never permissible targets of war, and every effort must be taken to avoid killing civilians. The deaths of civilians are justified only if they are unavoidable victims of a deliberate attack on a military target. Click to expand... By principles 1, 2, 4, 5, and 7, (basically every other one) abortion terrorism fails to really measure up to the moral standard. 1. There are other alternatives available. 2. The authority behind waging war against the practice is in no way, shape, or form "legitimate." Usually, it is an individual decision. 4. There really is not any reasonable chance of success. 5. There is no coherent "end game" beyond simply trying to get rid of abortion, so the re-establishment of peace is hardly being accounted for. And, finally... 7. The terrorists responsible for the attacks often wind up indiscriminately killing and injuring large numbers of people who are not actually "guilty." By any common sense moral standard, let alone the Christian variety, it's simply a bad idea. :shrug:

text: Since reality is so crazy it's easy to confuse satire with reality. I was a police officer for thirty years. I dealt with a man who was having sex with his daughter on orders from God. I was going to Hell for arresting him. Another man quit his job as a school teacher to fight smut. Every morning God spoke to him and gave him instructions. When I pointed out what he was doing was illegal he said, "There's God's law and Man's law. I follow God's law." In another case a 47-year old minister was caught having sex with a 14-year old girl. The girl's parents refused to let her testify and the congregation decided their minister was innocent and the girl was possessed by demons. An exorcism was clearly in order. And, a nursing home run by a church lost their license because an elderly man who pinched young women on their butt was wrapped in sheets and doused with scalding water to drive out the demons. He had to receive medical treatment for burns. The good news. The nursing home could still take care of elderly church members without a license. There is a reason what are called "mainstream" churches do not speak out against the Westboro Baptists and the Jim Jones and the other nuts. The line separating them is so thin.

text: I'm busy this days but had to post because not only was I so appalled and disgusted by the news....but because, this poses a very serious question to us all in the west. Italian police arrest migrants alleged to have thrown Christians overboard The survivors said they had boarded a rubber boat with 105 passengers aboard on Tuesday on the Libyan coast. During the crossing, the migrants from Nigeria and Ghana, believed to be Christians, were allegedly threatened with being abandoned at sea by some 15 other passengers from Ivory Coast, Senegal, Mali and Guinea-Bissau. A fight broke out and 12 passengers were allegedly thrown overboard to their deaths. The statement said the motive was that the victims “professed the Christian faith while the aggressors were Muslim”, Associated Press reported. Italian police arrest migrants alleged to have thrown Christians overboard | World news | The Guardian Our Prime Minister in Canada had opened some refugee status from Syria, but with the mandate that priorities will be given to persecuted minorities, especially Christians. Of course, the opposition parties didn't agree with that. They want the status to be available to everyone, regardless of creed. In fact, Justin Trudeau had stated that if he become PM, he'll accept 25,000 more Syrians into the country (of course, regardless of creed). What's wrong with that picture? Minorities, especially Christians, are being systematically killed. Muslims are not. That scenario in the migrant's boat reveals more eloquently than words. All those people - regardless of creed - are fleeing the same horrendous situations in their own countries. Non-Muslims are actually fleeing for their very lives. You'd think that at least, for all their shared plight, they would be setting differences aside and just be concerned of getting to their destination. But imagine that.....they still thought of killing Christians in that boat! Getting rid of some infidels! What does that scenario say? There are no moderate muslims! If you tolerate infidels (non-muslims), by definition - you aren't a muslim any more. That would be like a Christian saying he's a Christian but he does not believe in Jesus Christ! He may think he is a Christian, but he's not. Same with a muslim who tolerates and live with infidels - he may think he's a muslim, but actually he's not. So, think about importing all the refugees - regardless of their creed - into our borders! Keep in mind the latest PEW stats, too. http://www.debatepolitics.com/relig...ms-outnumber-christians-worldwide-2070-a.html Think about what could be ahead for us all, maybe 10 years from now. The decisions we make now will be the legacy - the problem - we'll be leaving to our future generation. Climate change is the least of our worries. This is beyond partisanship.

text: pinqy said: Huh? I didn't say that Christian charitable service in general is restricted. IF an individual group did practice illegal discrimination, then its benefits would be outweighed by that discrimination. For example, as a religious educational institution, Bob Jones University was tax exempt. However, it did not admit Blacks until 1971 (and then only if married and not mixed race) and from 1975 on, unmarried Blacks IF they were not in a mixed race relationship and did not advocate race mixing. The Supreme Court ruled in 1983 that Bob Jones University's First Ammendment righ based on their biblical beliefs against race mixing did not outweigh anti-discrimination laws. Click to expand... Ahhhh, that's not Christian doctrine. As I've said, the Constitution and our laws are based on Christian principles. The reason isn't the color of the skin. It's being "yoked with non-believers." BIG DIFFERENCE. Question: "What does the Bible say about interracial marriage?" Answer: The Old Testament Law commanded the Israelites not to engage in interracial marriage (Deuteronomy 7:3–4). However, the reason for this command was not skin color or ethnicity. Rather, it was religious. The reason God commanded against interracial marriage for the Jews was that people of other races were worshippers of false gods. The Israelites would be led astray from God if they intermarried with idol worshippers, pagans, or heathens. This is exactly what happened in Israel, according to Malachi 2:11. A similar principle of spiritual purity is laid out in the New Testament, but it has nothing to do with race: “Do not be yoked together with unbelievers. For what do righteousness and wickedness have in common? Or what fellowship can light have with darkness?” (2 Corinthians 6:14). Just as the Israelites (believers in the one true God) were commanded not to marry idolaters, so Christians (believers in the one true God) are commanded not to marry unbelievers. The Bible never says that interracial marriage is wrong. Anyone who forbids interracial marriage is doing so without biblical authority. A couple considering marriage needs to weigh many factors. While a difference in skin color should not be ignored, it absolutely should not be the determining factor in whether a couple should marry. An interracial couple may face discrimination and ridicule, and they should be prepared to respond to such prejudice in a biblical manner. “There is no difference between Jew and Gentile—the same Lord is Lord of all and richly blesses all who call on him” (Romans 10:12). A colorblind church and/or a Christian interracial marriage can be a powerful illustration of our equality in Christ. Read more: http://www.gotquestions.org/interracial-marriage.html#ixzz3bG2HPXYM Our church supports a missionary interracial couple in Nepal.

I'm happy an American socialist once corrected me on this way of thinking and broke me from the chains of it. Listen, there are countries with a multi-party system that have like 3, 4, 5 major parties and then a slew of minor parties participating it its respective democracy. The USA on the other hand is a two-party system . And it is so by design. You have Americans even boasting of the efficiency of limiting a democracy to no more than 2 parties that rule, and only conceptualizing democracy as "more than one party" (like Cuba). Even though democracy really only means "rule by majority" that concept rarely enters the American's mind, rather a rule by minorities is how Americans have bee taught over the last several decades to think. The United States has no monopoly on what constitutes a democracy. The USA thinks its the most democratic nation on earth like ISIS thinks it's the most Islamic nation on earth. Listen, Syria held an election, Assad won the vast majority of the votes, and not a plurality of votes like a lot of US Presidents are elected. So, the vast majority of Syrians voted him to stay their top executive leader and at the end of the day that's what democracy is . Secondly, Russia has separate branches of government. Which Putin has used and gotten okay from to enter places like Syria and Crimea. Obama and Trump never had to go to Congress or the American people for a damn thing related to bombing this or that in Russia or overthrowing governments in the Ukraine. Warhawks like McCain and Hillary Clinton had/have been in political office longer than Putin has. Okay, so, in the USA no President would be able to leave Presidential office and become Vice President, rule de facto from that position and then run later and get elected again as President. But Russia is not the USA. Worry less about Russia and more about the problems in the USA. And actually, I think it has worked out well for Russia by Putin switching positions so many times. He's a leader that has his feet planted on the ground enough to know American NGOs are often working for the CIA to cause cultural revolutions and problems in other countries. As for Syria, the conflict has been dragged out by the busy body USA conniving and fostering violence there because the American tax payers fund it while American super-rich with special interests don't have to privately finance the rebels and Syrian war. But they stand to make kickbacks $$$ I'm sure by getting in Saudi compliant leaders to run pipelines through Syria. Or who knows... the only thing sure is the US is not "there" out of pure love and benevolence.

More » July 1, 2016 Bangladesh Gunmen detonated explosives and took a number of people hostage at a restaurant in Dhaka. More » June 30, 2016 Egypt A gunman fatally shot a Christian minister in El Arish, the main town in northern Sinai. More » June 29, 2016 Turkey At least 44 people were killed and 238 people wounded in suicide bombings at Istanbul's main international aiport. Turkey blamed the Islamic State for the attack. More » June 28, 2016 Malaysia A grenade attack at a nightclub that injured eight people is thought to have been the first attack in Malaysia tied to the Islamic State. More » June 13, 2016 France A police captain was fatally stabbed and his companion was also killed at their home in a small town northwest of Paris. More » June 12, 2016 Florida A man who called 911 to proclaim allegiance to the Islamic State terrorist group, and who had been investigated in the past for possible terrorist ties, stormed a gay nightclub wielding an assault rifle and a pistol and carried out the worst mass shooting in United States history. More » June 7, 2016 Bangladesh A Hindu priest was attacked while riding a bicycle in a rural area not far from his home and hacked to death. More » June 5, 2016 Bangladesh A Christian man was hacked to death in his grocery store. More » May 8, 2016 Egypt Gunmen sprayed bullets on a police minibus as it passed through a Cairo district, killing eight plainclothes officers in an ambush. More » April 30, 2016 Bangladesh A Hindu tailor who had been briefly jailed several years ago over accusations that he made an unfavorable comment about the Prophet Muhammad was hacked to death near his shop in central Bangladesh. More » April 23, 2016 Bangladesh A university professor was hacked to death and nearly beheaded in an attack near his home in the northwest city of Rajshai. More » March 22, 2016 Belgium A series of deadly terrorist attacks struck Brussels, with two explosions at the city’s main international airport and a third in a subway station at the heart of the city, near the headquarters complex of the European Union. More » March 19, 2016 Turkey A suicide bombing on Istanbul's busiest thoroughfare killed three Israeli citizens and an Iranian. Two of the Israelis held dual Israeli-American citizenship. More » March 4, 2016 Yemen Gunmen killed 18 people at a nursing home founded by Mother Teresa and run by Christian nuns. More » Jan. 29, 2016 Yemen A bomb-packed car driven by a suicide attacker exploded at a checkpoint near the presidential palace in the southern city of Aden, killing at least eight people. More » Jan. 14, 2016 Indonesia ISIS claimed responsibility for explosions and gunfire that rocked central Jakarta, killing at least two civilians. More » Jan. 12, 2016 Turkey A Syrian suicide bomber set off an explosion in the historic central district of Istanbul, killing 10 people and wounding at least 15 others, in an attack the Turkish government attributed to ISIS. More » Jan. 11, 2016 France A teenager attacked a Jewish teacher with a machete in Marseille, and afterward told the police that he had carried out the attack in the name of God and the Islamic State. Jan. 8, 2016 Egypt Gunmen reportedly carrying an ISIS flag opened fire at a Red Sea resort, injuring at least two tourists. More » Jan. 7, 2016 Egypt ISIS claimed responsibility for an attack on a hotel in Cairo near the pyramids at Giza. No one was hurt. More » Jan. 7, 2016 Pennsylvania A man shot and wounded a Philadelphia police officer sitting in a patrol car in the name of Islam and the Islamic State, police said. More » Jan. 4, 2016 Libya Islamic State militants attempted to capture an oil port along Libya’s coast, in fighting that left at least seven people dead. Dec. 7, 2015 Yemen The Islamic State claimed responsibility for a car bomb that killed a provincial governor and eight of his body guards. More » Dec. 2, 2015 California A married couple shot and killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif. The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of terrorism inspired by ISIS. More » Nov. 26, 2015 Bangladesh ISIS claimed responsiblity for an attack on a Shiite mosque during evening prayer in which gunmen opened fire on worshipers with machine guns, killing one man and injuring three others. Because it's not at all uncommon for a disgruntled student to claim that a prof has made a sexual overture. Sad, but true. It's just so much easier not to tempt fate.

text: Chomsky said: Thanks for the kind words, Owl! You're pretty lovable yourself, you know! But let's face it - the most important choice in life, is our choice of our partner. I swear the advice I give all my kids, is: "In the important relationships in your life - romantic, business, friendships, whatever they may be - always pick better people than you! Surround yourself with good people!" I know it sounds crazy, but it's true! You'll never regret it, and good people will make you reach & grow to be a better person yourself. And that advice goes in spades in romantic relationships! Click to expand... Absolutely. I was extremely blessed to find and marry a good guy who has been my best friend for all these decades. And he also never gave me a reason to doubt his fidelity--he has been the one person in my life I could count on unconditionally to be there for me when I needed him and to be a witness to my life. And I have done my best to be the same for him. Does that mean that we have never been disappointed or frustrated or angry with each other? Of course not. But when you marry the right person, you work through those times and emerge stronger. Vice President Pence is my idea of a real man who loves his wife and chooses not to put her in a position of having to put aside doubts. I believe a real woman gives the same gift to her husband. Blessed are those who look for and achieve that kind of marriage.

snippet: Dinosaurs Were on Noah's Ark, Says Creationist Ken Ham Do you want to know what really happened to dinosaurs? Although he doesn't reveal exactly what happened to them after that, Ham announced in a new radio ad*posted to YouTube on…
text: Dinosaurs Were on Noah's Ark, Says Creationist Ken Ham Do you want to know what really happened to dinosaurs? Well, president and founder of Answers in Genesis-U.S. and the Creation Museum, Ken Ham, says they were in Noah's Ark. Although he doesn't reveal exactly what happened to them after that, Ham announced in a new radio ad*posted to YouTube on Monday*that God created dinosaurs and he told Noah to take pairs of them into the ark before the biblical flood. Ken Ham Irked by 'Hypocrisy' of Secularists Over 'Loch Ness' Story "Evolution has used dinosaurs more than almost anything else to indoctrinate children into millions of years of evolutionary ideas.* Evolution has claimed dinosaurs evolved over 200 million years ago. That no humans ever lived with them…that some mysterious event led to the extinction of dinosaurs," says Ham in the one-minute ad titled "What Really Happened to the Dinosaurs?" "But the Bible gives a different history. God tells us he created all land animals the same day he created man about 6,000 years ago and what's more there were even dinosaurs on Noah's Ark because God told Noah to take pairs of every kind of land animal. You see, dinosaurs are no mystery at all if you accept the Bible's account of creation," notes Ham. A*Slate report*mocked Ham last year for his campaign to "take dinosaurs back" from "secular humanists" who have held dinosaurs hostage for decades. "Creationists, in Ham's view, should use dinosaurs as star attractions to get the public to imbibe the religious swill he and his organization peddle. Dinosaurs are unlikely symbols of religious fundamentalism," notes the report. "The first dinosaurs evolved about 230 million years ago, and, with the exception of birds, perished about 66 million years ago. Archaic humans didn't originate until 60 million years later, so it's not surprising that Stegosaurus, Triceratops, and kin aren't mentioned in the Bible. Of course, Ham and like-minded literalists would beg to differ," it adds. Yahoo*reported last year*that the Creation Museum had its lowest attendance since its opening in 2007. It noted that 280,000 people visited the museum in the last fiscal year compared to the 404,000 who visited in 2007. Creation Museum's "Noah's Cafe," Ark Encounter Vice President Michael Zovath chalked up the attendance drop to the bad economy while the report pointed to its heavy advertising. "It's a way to get kids to come to the museum, that's the whole purpose of advertising," Zovath says of the ads. "The common response is, well, you're trying to attract children to your museum so you can teach them something we don't believe in. That's probably true," he notes. "But secular museums and most natural history museums, when they run a dinosaur exhibit it's to promote attendance, and they're trying to teach kids things we don't believe in." Read more at* http://www.christianpost.com/news/di...qbAJB24Zxco.99

text: I dislike Vox as a source, but I found a couple of items interesting: Insurance markets are complicated. But the story of Obamacare's 2016 premium increase is actually pretty simple: Many health plans — even those with decades of experience selling insurance — underestimated how sick health law enrollees would be. Click to expand... Only 8000 enrollees and managed to lose 9 milion. Ouch. This meant that in 2014, many insurers spent more paying out medical bills than members paid in premiums. Premera Blue Cross Blue Shield of Alaska lost $9 million covering just under 8,000 Obamacare enrollees that year. In Colorado, Rocky Mountain HMO found medical bills to be about 36 percent higher than premiums. Click to expand... There are other insurers who didn't have this problem, who priced correctly and turned a profit. But they're in the minority of those selling on the health law's new marketplaces. "Many more insurers lost money than made money in 2014," says Larry Levitt, senior vice president for special initiatives at the Kaiser Family Foundation. Click to expand... Why Obamacare premiums are spiking in 2016 - Vox

text: So, let me see if I have this, then. God doesn't cause the rape to happen. But he causes the pregnancy to happen. Right? Despite how the pregnancy could not have happened without the rape. The Christian teaching is that god watches the rape, does nothing to stop it, and then decides to put a baby in the victim, knowing full well the emotional and physical turmoil it will cause her, and piles that on top of the current turmoil she is experiencing, as she is presently being raped. He could choose to place this child into a loving union, or simply send it to the woman later, when she is in a loving union. But no, god chooses to put the child inside a rape victim, meaning a worse environment for the child, and inflict pain and suffering on the woman. That is a choice that could only be described as sadistic. I do not think there is any outcome in this discussion where Mourdoch's god is not evil for doing this. code1211 said: Dial it back a notch and let the real positions guide the debate. Click to expand... Okay, let's dispense with the theological questions and do exactly that. Mourdoch's real position is that a woman should not have the free choice about when to or not to reproduce. His position is that in a conflict where a fetus and a woman are both attempting to using the woman's body, neither of whom have any legally recognizable consent from the other about it, the fetus has priority. His position is that the pain and suffering of a living woman is irrelevant compared to the possible future of a creature that has no mind yet. Those are the real positions here. Mourdoch's position is that if a man wants to have a baby by a woman, and she does not want to have his child, and he rapes her in order to make that pregnancy happen, then his choice trumps hers. The standard set in Roe v Wade that limits abortions to the first 24 weeks of pregnancy, is a compromise between the ideas of banning abortion and fully permitting it. What is happening now is that the ban side is reneging on the compromise.

[note: this isn't "new data," this is just someone bothering to look at all the available data--GB] Premiums for silver plans on the federal insurance exchanges are slated to increase an average of 5.8 percent in the eight states where all data is available, according to an analysis by Avalere Health. For the lowest-cost silver plans, that increase will be 4.5 percent, or an average of $378 per year. . . “While recent public attention has focused on a subset of plans that filed for premium increases of 10 percent or more, these data reveal that most plans are proposing more modest increases,” said the group’s senior vice president, Caroline Pearson.
